summary: Breast cancer is a cancer that starts in breast tissue when cells in the breast change and grow out of control, forming a mass called a tumor. It can be 'in situ' (not spread) or 'invasive' (spread to nearby tissues, lymph nodes, or metastasize to other parts of the body). It is the most common invasive cancer in women globally and the second most common type of cancer in women in the United States, though it can also affect men.
causes: Interaction of environmental factors and genetic susceptibility
Mutations in DNA repair genes (e.g., TP53, BRCA1, BRCA2)
Inherited BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations impairing DNA repair
Estrogen oxidative metabolites causing DNA damage
risk_factors: History of benign breast disease (e.g., atypical ductal hyperplasia, fibrocystic changes)
Inherited genetic predisposition (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2, PALB2, TP53, PTEN, PALB1 mutations)
Reproductive history increasing estrogen exposure (early menstruation, late or no first birth, late menopause)
Hormone replacement therapy for menopause (especially combined progesterone/estrogen)
Radiation exposure to breast/chest (especially before age 30)
Circadian disruptions related to shift-work and routine late-night eating
Exposure to certain chemicals (PCBs, PAHs, organic solvents)
symptoms: New lump or thickening in breast or armpit
Change in the size or shape of the breast
Dimpling or puckering of breast skin ('orange peel' appearance)
Unusual nipple discharge (sudden, bloody, or unilateral)
Pain in any area of the breast
Substantial breast swelling and redness (inflammatory breast cancer)
Shortness of breath (distant spread, lung metastases)
Speech, vision, memory, or behavioral disruptions (brain metastases)
diagnosis: Breast biopsy (core needle biopsy, fine-needle aspiration)
Blood chemistry tests (BMP, CMP, electrolyte panel)
treatments: Surgery (mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, breast-conserving surgery, sentinel lymph node biopsy, breast reconstruction)
Chemotherapy (e.g., cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, fluorouracil, paclitaxel, cisplatin)
Hormone therapy (e.g., tamoxifen, aromatase inhibitors, GnRH-targeted drugs, CDK4/6 inhibitors, mTOR inhibitors)
Targeted therapy (e.g., HER2-targeted antibodies, PARP inhibitors, PIK3CA inhibitors)
Supportive care (e.g., antiemetics, cold caps, antidepressants, physical therapy, CBT, yoga, peer support)
